chapter.title: &oa;
chapter.para: &oa; is a central storage management system which supports &ceph; storage cluster. With &oa; you can control everything from a central management interface. It is no longer necessary to be familiar with the inner workings of the &ceph; storage tools. Cluster management tasks can be carried out by either using &oa;'s intuitive Web interface, or via its REST API.

sect1.title: Installing Required Packages

tip.para: &oa; will work correctly only if it is the only Web-based application on the specific host. Do not share the host with another Web application such as Calamari.

sect1.title: &oa; Initial Setup
sect1.para: After the packages are installed, run the actual &oa; setup:
oaconfig install will start a number of services, initialize the &oa; database, and scan the system for pools and volumes to include.
By default, oaconfig creates an administrative user account openattic, with the same password as the user name. As a security precaution, we strongly recommend to change this password immediately:
sect1.screen: sudo oaconfig changepassword openattic Changing password for user 'openattic' Password: <enter password> Password (again): <re-enter password> Password changed successfully for user 'openattic'
sect1.para: Now your &oa; storage system can be managed by the Web user interface.

sect1.title: &oa; Web User Interface
sect1.para: &oa; can be managed using a Web user interface. Open a Web browser and navigate to http://www.example.org/openattic. To log in, use the default user name openattic and the corresponding password.
The &oa; user interface is graphically divided into a top menu pane and a content pane.
The right part of the top pane includes a link to the current user settings, and a Logout link. The rest of the top pane includes the main &oa; menu.

sect1.title: Dashboard
sect1.para: Dashboard shows the overall statistics of the running &ceph; cluster. By default it shows the following widgets: Cluster Status, Cluster Utilization, and I/O Performance
The Cluster Status widget tells whether the cluster is operating correctly. In case a problem is detected, you can view the detailed error message by clicking the subtitle inside the widget.
The Cluster Utilization widget shows the storage utilization in time. You can activate or deactivate the following charts:

listitem.para: Bytes total - shows the total storage size.
Bytes available - shows the remaining available space.
Bytes used - shows the occupied space.

sect1.para: The I/O Performance widget shows the read/write per second statistics in time.

tip.title: More Details on Mouse Over
tip.para: If you move the mouse pointer over any of the displayed charts, it will show you more details related to the pointed date and time in a pop-up window.

sect1.title: &ceph; Related Tasks
sect1.para: &oa;'s main menu lists &ceph; related tasks. Currently, the following tasks are relevant: OSDs, RBDs, Pools, Minions and CRUSH Map.

sect2.title: Listing OSD Nodes
sect2.para: To list all available OSD nodes, click OSDs from the main menu.
The list shows each OSD's name, host name, status, and weight.

sect2.title: Managing RADOS Block Devices (RBDs)
sect2.para: To list all available RADOS block devices, click RBDs from the main menu.
The list shows each device's name, the related pool name, size of the device, and how many percents are already occupied.
To view more detailed information about a device, activate its check box in the very left column:

sect3.title: Deleting RBDs
sect3.para: To delete a device or a group of devicesws, activate their check boxes in the very left column and click Delete in the top left of the RBDs table:

sect3.title: Adding RBDs
sect3.para: To add a new device, click Add in the top left of the RBDs table and do the following on the Create RBD screen:

step.para: Enter the name of the new device. Refer to for naming limitations.
Select the cluster that will store the new pool.
Select the pool from which the new RBD device will be created.
Specify the size of the new device. If you click the use max link above, the maximum pool size is populated.
To fine tune the device parameters, click Expert settings and activate or deactivate displayed options.

sect2.title: Managing Pools

tip.title: More Information on Pools

sect2.para: To list all available pools, click Pools from the main menu.
The list shows each pool's name, ID, the percentage of used space, the number of placement groups, replica size, type ('replicated' or 'erasure'), erasure code profile, and the crush ruleset.
To view more detailed information about a pool, activate its check box in the very left column:

sect3.title: Deleting Pools
sect3.para: To delete a pool or a group of pools, activate their check boxes in the very left column and click Delete in the top left of the pools table:

sect3.title: Adding Pools
sect3.para: To add a new pool, click Add in the top left of the pools table and do the following on the Create Ceph pool screen:

step.para: Enter the name of the new pool. Refer to for naming limitations.
Select the cluster that will store the new pool.
Select the pool type. Pools can be either replicated or erasure coded.
Specify the number of the pool's placement groups.
For a replicated pool, specify the replica size.

sect2.title: Listing &sminion;s

important.title: &salt; Only Deployment
important.para: The Minions tab is only available when the cluster is deployed via &salt;. Refer to for more information on &salt;.

sect2.para: Click Minions from the main menu to view the list of &sminion;s available on the cluster.
Each minion is represented by its host name, public IP address, cluster ID it belongs to, node role (for example 'admin', 'storage', or 'master'), and key acceptance status.

sect2.title: Viewing the Cluster &crushmap;
sect2.para: Click CRUSH Map from the main menu to view cluster &crushmap;.
In the Physical setup pane, you can see the structure of the cluster as described by the &crushmap;.
In the Replication rules pane, you can view individual rulesets after selecting one of them from the Content from the drop-down list.
